An Adverbial Clause modifies a Principal Sentence like an Adverb, and is introduced by Conjunctions.

(For examples see Lat. Prim. Appendix XI.)

The Adverb shows W lcy, When, or How: and so does an Adverbial Ulause.

The tense of the verb in the Adverbial Clause is determined by the tense of the Principal Verb.

Primary tenses (Present, Future, and Perfect with ‘have ) are followed by Primary.

Historia tenses (Imperfect, Pluperfeer„ and Aorist, or Perfect without ‘ have ') are followed by Historic.

108. Magum—one of the priestly order in Persia. Cambyses had put to death his brother Smerdis. In the absence of Cambyses, one of the Magi, taking advantage of an accidental likeness, pretended to be Smerdis‚ alleging that he had not been put to death as generally believed, and made himself king. Cambyses died before he could put down the revolt, and Smerdis reigned for some months before he was detected ancl slain by some conspirators, one of whom, Darius, was made king.
